precautions: Wear masks
Wash hands
Physical distancing
Get vaccinated
actions: Isolate if symptomatic
Seek testing
Monitor oxygen levels
Seek medical care if severe

precautions: Annual flu vaccination
Cover coughs/sneezes
Avoid close contact
Wash hands
actions: Rest and hydrate
Take antivirals if prescribed
Stay home until fever subsides

precautions: Avoid mosquito bites
Use repellents
Bed nets
Eliminate standing water
actions: Stay hydrated
Seek medical care
Avoid aspirin/NSAIDs
Hospitalization if severe

precautions: Mosquito nets
Antimalarial prophylaxis
Indoor spraying
actions: Seek treatment
Take prescribed antimalarials
Monitor complications

precautions: BCG vaccination
Good ventilation
Avoid close contact
actions: Seek TB testing
Start DOTS therapy
Complete treatment course

precautions: Safe sex
Avoid sharing needles
Regular testing
PrEP
actions: Get tested
Start ART
Adhere to treatment

precautions: Safe water
Food hygiene
Sanitation
Vaccination
actions: Oral rehydration
IV fluids if severe
Antibiotics if prescribed

precautions: Vaccination
Avoid sharing needles
Safe sex
actions: Testing
Antivirals if chronic
Monitor liver function

precautions: MMR vaccination
Avoid contact
Good ventilation
actions: Seek medical care
Supportive care
Vitamin A supplementation

precautions: Vaccination
Avoid close contact
actions: Isolate until blisters scab
Relieve itching
Seek care if complications

symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
precautions: Vaccination
Be hygenic
actions: Take good care of chronic conditions(if any)
Limit contact with cigaratte and cigarrate smoke

precautions: Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke
Practice good hand hygiene (wash hands frequently)
Cover coughs and sneezes; use tissues or elbow crease
Stay away from people with respiratory infections when contagious
actions: Rest, stay hydrated, and use humidified air
See a clinician if cough persists >3 weeks, breathing difficulty, or high fever
Use prescribed bronchodilators or inhaled medications if indicated

symptoms: High-pitched 'whoop' sound on inspiration (especially in children)
Runny nose and mild fever initially
precautions: Vaccination (DTaP for children, Tdap booster for adolescents/adults)
Avoid contact with infants or unvaccinated people if symptomatic
Cover coughs, practice hand hygiene, and isolate during contagious period
actions: Seek medical care promptly—antibiotics (macrolides) may be prescribed
Isolate infected individuals until completion of recommended antibiotics
Provide supportive care; monitor infants closely for apnea or feeding problems

symptoms: Sudden sore throat with pain on swallowing
Swollen, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes
Tonsillar exudates or red swollen tonsils
Absence of cough (helps distinguish from viral URI)
precautions: Avoid close contact with infected persons
Good hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette
Do not share eating utensils or toothbrushes while symptomatic
actions: See a healthcare provider for testing (rapid antigen or throat culture)
Start antibiotics (if confirmed) and complete full course
Stay home until 24 hours after starting effective antibiotics and fever-free

symptoms: Neck stiffness (inability to flex neck forward)
precautions: Vaccination where available (e.g., meningococcal, pneumococcal, Hib)
Avoid sharing utensils or close contact with people with suspected meningitis
Practice good hand hygiene
actions: Seek emergency medical care immediately
Early empiric antibiotics for suspected bacterial meningitis
Close contacts may need prophylactic antibiotics or vaccination per public-health guidance

symptoms: Expanding erythema migrans (bull's-eye) rash at tick bite site
If untreated: cardiac (heart block), neurological (facial palsy, radiculopathy) or chronic arthritis
precautions: Use insect repellent with DEET or picaridin in tick-prone areas
Wear long sleeves/pants and tuck pants into socks; perform tick checks
Shower soon after possible exposure and remove ticks promptly
actions: Remove ticks promptly and properly (with fine-tipped tweezers)
See healthcare provider for assessment; antibiotics may be prescribed if indicated
Monitor for late signs (neurologic or rheumatologic) and follow-up if symptoms develop

symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath if pulmonary involvement
precautions: Avoid swimming or wading in water possibly contaminated with animal urine
Wear protective clothing when handling animals or working in contaminated environments
Control rodents and maintain clean water supplies
actions: Seek medical attention for suspected infection—antibiotics (doxycycline, penicillin) may be given
Hospitalize and provide supportive care for severe disease (renal or hepatic involvement)
Report outbreaks to public-health authorities as required

symptoms: Cutaneous: painless ulcer with black necrotic center
Inhalation: flu-like symptoms progressing to severe respiratory distress
Gastrointestinal: severe abdominal pain, vomiting, bloody diarrhea
precautions: Avoid contact with contaminated animal products and soil in endemic areas
Use personal protective equipment when handling potentially infected animals/materials
Vaccination for at-risk occupational groups where available
actions: Seek urgent medical care—early antibiotic therapy is critical
Report suspected cases to public-health authorities immediately
Provide supportive care and consider antitoxin for severe systemic disease

symptoms: Flu-like symptoms: fever, muscle aches, swollen lymph nodes
In immunocompromised: severe encephalitis, confusion, seizures
In congenital infection: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications
Eye pain or visual disturbance when ocular disease present
precautions: Avoid handling cat litter if pregnant; change litter daily or have another person do it
Cook meat thoroughly and avoid raw or undercooked meat
Wash fruits and vegetables before eating
actions: Pregnant or immunocompromised persons with exposure should seek medical advice/testing
Specific antiparasitic therapy (pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine with folinic acid) for indicated cases
Follow obstetric guidance and fetal monitoring for congenital risk

symptoms: Mononucleosis-like illness: fever, sore throat, swollen glands, fatigue
In newborns (congenital CMV): hearing loss, microcephaly, developmental delay
In immunocompromised: severe systemic disease affecting liver, lungs, GI tract, or eyes
precautions: Practice hand hygiene, especially when caring for young children or changing diapers
Use safe sex practices to reduce transmission
Screen/monitor high-risk pregnant women or immunocompromised patients when indicated
actions: Seek medical evaluation if severe illness or pregnancy exposure suspected
Antiviral therapy (ganciclovir/valganciclovir) may be used in severe or congenital cases
Monitor neonates with congenital infection for hearing and developmental issues

symptoms: Wheezing and difficulty breathing (especially in infants)
Poor feeding or lethargy in infants
precautions: Practice hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette
Avoid close contact with high-risk infants if you are symptomatic
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces and avoid sharing utensils
actions: Supportive care: hydration, oxygen therapy for severe cases
Seek prompt care for infants with difficulty breathing or poor feeding
High-risk infants may receive preventive monoclonal antibody per clinical guidelines

precautions: Frequent handwashing and respiratory etiquette
Avoid close contact with sick individuals
Disinfect commonly touched surfaces
actions: Rest, fluids, saline nasal irrigation and symptomatic care (decongestants, analgesics as appropriate)
See a clinician if severe symptoms, high fever, or breathing difficulty occur
Stay home while symptomatic to reduce spread

symptoms: Croup (barking cough and stridor) in young children
precautions: Good hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette
Avoid contact with people showing respiratory symptoms
Disinfect surfaces in childcare settings
actions: Supportive care: humidified air, hydration, oxygen if needed
Seek medical attention for stridor, breathing difficulty or dehydration
Hospitalize severe pediatric cases for airway support if necessary

symptoms: Gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, diarrhea) in some cases
precautions: Maintain and disinfect building water systems (cooling towers, hot tubs, plumbing) per public-health guidance
Avoid inhaling aerosolized water from poorly maintained systems
Follow local public-health recommendations for prevention
actions: Seek medical care—diagnostic testing (urinary antigen, culture) and chest imaging may be done
Start appropriate antibiotics (macrolide or fluoroquinolone) as recommended
Report clusters to public-health authorities for source investigation

symptoms: Red cracked lips and strawberry tongue
Swollen hands and feet with redness
precautions: No known prevention—early recognition is key
Prompt evaluation of persistent fever in young children
Follow pediatric infectious-disease and cardiology guidance
actions: Urgent medical evaluation—IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin) and aspirin therapy often started
Echocardiography to assess for coronary artery involvement
Close follow-up with pediatric cardiology

symptoms: Nausea and vomiting in some cases
precautions: Strict handwashing after using toilet and before eating
Safe food handling and sanitation
Avoid preparing food for others while symptomatic
actions: Hydration and electrolyte replacement; seek care for severe or bloody diarrhea
Antibiotics for severe cases or as recommended by local guidelines
Report outbreaks to public-health authorities when indicated

precautions: Cook poultry thoroughly and avoid cross-contamination
Practice safe food handling and hand hygiene
Avoid untreated water and unpasteurized dairy products
actions: Hydration and supportive care; seek care for severe illness
Antibiotics for severe or high-risk cases per clinician
Report to public-health authorities if part of a suspected outbreak

symptoms: Headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance in invasive disease
In pregnant women: flu-like symptoms then possible fetal infection (stillbirth, preterm delivery)
Neonatal sepsis or meningitis in newborns
precautions: Avoid high-risk foods during pregnancy (unpasteurized dairy, deli meats unless heated, refrigerated smoked seafood)
Practice good food hygiene and proper refrigeration
Follow guidance for at-risk populations (pregnant, elderly, immunocompromised)
actions: Seek prompt medical attention—antibiotic therapy (ampicillin ± gentamicin) for invasive disease
Hospital care and monitoring for severe cases or neonates
Report cases to public-health authorities as required

precautions: Cook eggs and poultry thoroughly and avoid cross-contamination
Practice hand hygiene after contact with animals (especially reptiles, poultry)
Avoid unpasteurized dairy and improperly handled food
actions: Hydration and supportive care; seek care for severe or prolonged illness
Antibiotics for severe invasive disease or high-risk patients per clinician
Report outbreaks to public-health authorities if suspected

symptoms: Watery diarrhea that may progress to bloody diarrhea (esp. E. coli O157:H7)
In severe cases: hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) signs—reduced urine, pallor, bruising
precautions: Cook ground beef thoroughly and avoid unpasteurized dairy/juices
Practice strict hand hygiene after animal contact and restroom use
Prevent cross-contamination in the kitchen
actions: Hydration and medical evaluation for bloody diarrhea or severe symptoms
Avoid routine antibiotics for some strains unless indicated; follow clinical guidance
Seek urgent care for signs of HUS (reduced urination, bleeding, pallor)

symptoms: Oral thrush: white plaques on tongue and oral mucosa
Vaginal yeast infection: itching, thick white discharge, dysuria
Cutaneous candidiasis: red, itchy rash in skin folds
In invasive disease: fever, chills, signs of sepsis in hospitalized patients
precautions: Maintain good hygiene and dry skin folds well
Avoid unnecessary antibiotic use which can predispose to overgrowth
Follow safe sexual practices if recurrent vaginal infections
actions: Topical or oral antifungal therapy depending on site and severity
Evaluate for underlying predispositions (diabetes, immunosuppression)
Hospital management and systemic antifungals for invasive candidiasis

symptoms: Often asymptomatic or mild respiratory illness (cough, fever, chest pain)
Flu-like symptoms with fatigue and chills
Chronic pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis in some
Disseminated disease: fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy
precautions: Avoid exposure to bat or bird droppings (caves, chicken coops) where endemic
Use protective equipment and dust suppression when disturbing contaminated soil
Follow occupational safety recommendations in endemic areas
actions: Mild cases may resolve without treatment; antifungal therapy (itraconazole) for moderate to severe disease
Amphotericin B for severe/disseminated infection
Seek medical care if symptoms persist or worsen

symptoms: Chest pain and shortness of breath
Skin lesions (verrucous or ulcerated) in disseminated disease
Weight loss, fatigue, and systemic symptoms
precautions: Avoid activities that disturb moist soil in endemic regions
Use protective equipment if occupational exposure likely
Follow local public-health guidance in endemic areas
actions: Antifungal therapy (itraconazole for mild/moderate; amphotericin B for severe disease)
Seek healthcare evaluation for persistent respiratory or skin symptoms
Monitor for dissemination in immunocompromised individuals

symptoms: Fever and cough in pulmonary infection
Meningeal signs (headache, neck stiffness, confusion) in cryptococcal meningitis
Focal neurologic deficits and altered mental status in severe cases
precautions: Limit exposure to environments with bird droppings if immunocompromised
Use protective equipment for high-risk occupational exposure
Vaccination is not available—manage risk through exposure control
actions: Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B ± flucytosine followed by fluconazole for meningitis)
Urgent medical care for neurologic signs
Long-term antifungal therapy and monitoring in immunocompromised patients

symptoms: Hypoxia (low oxygen levels) on exertion or at rest
precautions: Prophylaxis (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) for high-risk immunocompromised patients (HIV with low CD4, transplant recipients)
Minimize exposure to respiratory pathogens in immunosuppressed individuals
Prompt evaluation of early respiratory symptoms in at-risk patients
actions: Start appropriate antimicrobial therapy (TMP-SMX) with adjunctive corticosteroids if indicated
Hospitalize for oxygen support if hypoxic
Investigate and manage underlying immune suppression

symptoms: Round, scaly, ring-like rash with central clearing (tinea corporis)
Itching and redness in affected area
Athlete's foot: scaling, cracking, itching between toes
Tinea capitis: scaly patches on the scalp, hair loss, black dots
precautions: Keep skin clean and dry; avoid shared footwear/towels
Use antifungal powders in shoes and on feet if prone to infection
Avoid walking barefoot in communal wet areas (locker rooms, pools)
actions: Topical antifungal agents for localized infections (azoles or allylamines)
Oral antifungals for extensive or scalp/nail involvement
Maintain hygiene and treat close contacts if recurrent

symptoms: Otorrhea (ear discharge) if tympanic membrane perforation
precautions: Reduce smoke exposure and limit pacifier use in infants
Breastfeed infants when possible and follow immunization schedule
Practice hand hygiene to reduce upper respiratory infections
actions: Analgesics for pain relief (acetaminophen/ibuprofen as appropriate)
Watchful waiting for uncomplicated cases in select children; antibiotics per guidelines if severe or persistent
Refer/ENT evaluation for recurrent or complicated cases

symptoms: Eye discharge (watery in viral; purulent in bacterial)
precautions: Avoid touching eyes and practice hand hygiene
Do not share towels, pillows, or eye cosmetics
Stay home from school/work until non-contagious if advised
actions: Viral: supportive care (cold compresses, artificial tears)
Bacterial: topical antibiotics if prescribed by clinician
Seek urgent care for severe pain, vision changes, or intense redness

symptoms: Eyelid scarring and inward turning of eyelashes (trichiasis) in chronic disease
precautions: Improve facial hygiene and sanitation in endemic areas
Avoid sharing towels and bedding
Community-wide interventions (SAFE strategy): Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvements
actions: Antibiotic therapy (oral azithromycin or topical tetracycline) as recommended
Surgery for trichiasis to prevent corneal damage
Public-health measures to reduce transmission and re-infection

symptoms: Anemia and pancytopenia in visceral disease
Skin ulcers or lesions in cutaneous forms
precautions: Use insect repellent and bed nets in endemic areas
Wear protective clothing and minimize outdoor exposure at dusk/dawn
Control sandfly habitats and reservoir animals where possible
actions: Seek medical diagnosis and antileishmanial therapy (e.g., amphotericin formulations or pentavalent antimonials depending on region and form)
Supportive care for nutritional and hematologic complications
Report cases to public-health authorities if part of control programs

symptoms: Fever and lymphadenitis in acute stages
Lymphedema and elephantiasis in chronic disease
precautions: Use insect repellent and mosquito nets in endemic areas
Participate in community mass drug administration (MDA) programs where available
Avoid mosquito exposure during peak biting times
actions: Antiparasitic therapy (e.g., ivermectin, albendazole, diethylcarbamazine) per program guidelines
Hygiene and management of lymphedema to prevent complications
Community/ public-health control measures to reduce transmission

symptoms: Eye lesions leading to visual impairment and blindness
precautions: Avoid blackfly exposure in endemic riverine areas
Support and participate in mass drug administration programs (e.g., ivermectin)
Use protective clothing and insect repellent where applicable
actions: Mass drug administration with ivermectin per local program
Ocular care and management of skin disease symptoms
Public-health surveillance and vector control

symptoms: Itchy skin or rash at penetration site
Fever, chills, cough in early stages
Abdominal pain, diarrhea, or blood in stool (intestinal forms)
Urinary symptoms and blood in urine (urogenital forms)
Long-term: liver fibrosis, bladder pathology, increased risk of bladder cancer
precautions: Avoid swimming or wading in freshwater in endemic areas
Use safe water sources and sanitation improvements
Participate in community treatment programs
actions: Antiparasitic therapy (praziquantel) per local guidelines
Health education and sanitation improvements to reduce reinfection
Monitor and manage chronic complications with medical and surgical care as needed

symptoms: Abdominal discomfort and possible intestinal obstruction in heavy infection
Cough and wheeze during larval migration (pulmonary phase)
Nutritional deficiencies and growth impairment in children
precautions: Practice hand hygiene and wash fruits/vegetables
Use sanitation and prevent open defecation
Wash hands before eating and after soil contact
actions: Anthelmintic therapy (albendazole or mebendazole) as prescribed
Mass drug administration in endemic settings
Surgical intervention for intestinal obstruction if necessary

symptoms: In heavy infections: growth and cognitive impairment in children
precautions: Wear shoes to avoid skin contact with contaminated soil
Improve sanitation and avoid open defecation
Health education and hygiene promotion
actions: Anthelmintic therapy (albendazole or mebendazole)
Iron supplementation and nutritional support for anemic patients
Community deworming programs in endemic areas

symptoms: Rectal prolapse in severe pediatric cases
precautions: Practice sanitation and hand hygiene
Avoid ingestion of soil or unwashed produce
Participate in community deworming where provided
actions: Anthelmintic therapy (e.g., albendazole, mebendazole) per guidance
Nutrition and monitoring for growth in children
Public-health interventions to reduce transmission

symptoms: Cough and respiratory symptoms during migration
Severe disseminated disease in immunosuppressed: sepsis-like picture
precautions: Avoid contact with contaminated soil and wear protective footwear
Screen high-risk individuals before immunosuppression
Improve sanitation and hygiene
actions: Anthelmintic therapy (ivermectin preferred)
Hospitalize and treat severe or disseminated infection aggressively
Screen and treat contacts in endemic areas if indicated

symptoms: Passage of tapeworm segments in stool (proglottids)
Weight loss or malnutrition in heavy infection
precautions: Cook pork/beef thoroughly and practice good food hygiene
Avoid consumption of raw or undercooked meat
Proper sanitation to interrupt fecal-oral transmission
actions: Antiparasitic therapy (praziquantel or niclosamide) as prescribed
Stool testing and treatment of household contacts if indicated
Food safety education

symptoms: Neurocysticercosis: seizures, headaches, focal neurologic deficits
Increased intracranial pressure in severe cases
precautions: Cook pork thoroughly and maintain sanitation
Wash hands and food to prevent fecal-oral transmission
Treat human carriers of intestinal tapeworm to prevent spread
actions: Neuroimaging and neurologic evaluation for suspected neurocysticercosis
Antiparasitic therapy (albendazole ± praziquantel) plus anti-inflammatory and antiepileptic management when indicated
Surgical intervention in selected cases with mass effect or hydrocephalus

symptoms: Cystic lesions in liver (pain, biliary obstruction) or lungs (cough, chest pain)
Abdominal mass or discomfort depending on location
precautions: Avoid feeding dogs raw offal in endemic areas; deworm dogs per guidelines
Practice hand hygiene after handling dogs
Proper slaughterhouse hygiene and meat inspection
actions: Imaging for diagnosis and specialist referral (surgical removal or percutaneous drainage for certain cysts)
Albendazole therapy pre- and/or post-procedure as indicated
Public-health measures for animal hosts to reduce transmission

symptoms: Undulating fever and sweats (especially at night)
precautions: Avoid unpasteurized dairy products and raw milk
Use protective equipment when handling animals or animal tissues
Vaccinate livestock where programs exist
actions: Seek medical care—combination antibiotic therapy (e.g., doxycycline + rifampin or doxycycline + streptomycin) as prescribed
Prolonged treatment for preventing relapse
Reportable disease in many jurisdictions—notify public health if required

symptoms: Skin ulcer at site of entry with regional lymphadenopathy (ulceroglandular form)
precautions: Avoid handling wild animals or use protective gear and gloves
Prevent tick and insect bites with repellents and protective clothing
Practice safe food and water handling
actions: Seek medical evaluation—antibiotics (e.g., streptomycin, gentamicin, or doxycycline) are recommended
Report to public-health authorities as appropriate
Provide supportive care for severe pulmonary disease

symptoms: Dry cough and shortness of breath
Chest pain and nonproductive cough in pneumonia cases
precautions: Practice good hygiene around birds and pet birds; avoid exposure to droppings and secretions
Quarantine and test sick birds; use protective equipment when handling birds
Avoid purchasing or handling sick birds
actions: Seek medical care—tetracycline or macrolide antibiotics are commonly used
Report suspected zoonotic transmission to public-health or veterinary services
Provide supportive care for pneumonia and monitor respiratory status

symptoms: Hepatitis with abnormal liver enzymes in some patients
precautions: Avoid contact with birth tissues or fluids from farm animals without protective equipment
Use appropriate PPE for at-risk occupations (veterinarians, abattoir workers)
Control animal infection and follow farm biosecurity measures
actions: Seek medical care—doxycycline is first-line for acute Q fever
Long-term management and specialist care for chronic Q fever (e.g., endocarditis) if present
Notify public-health authorities when occupational exposures occur

symptoms: Wheezing or chest tightness in some patients
precautions: Practice hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette
Avoid close contact with people who have respiratory infections
Maintain good ventilation in crowded settings
actions: Clinical assessment and chest imaging if pneumonia suspected
Macrolide or doxycycline therapy per local guidelines for symptomatic bacterial infection
Supportive care: fluids, rest, antipyretics

symptoms: Diarrhea (watery or bloody depending on cause)
Dehydration signs: reduced urine, dry mouth, dizziness
precautions: Handwashing, especially after restroom use and before food preparation
Safe food handling and water sanitation
Exclude food handlers with vomiting/diarrhea from work until cleared
actions: Oral rehydration and electrolyte replacement
Seek medical attention for severe dehydration, bloody diarrhea, high fever, or persistent symptoms
Use antibiotics only when indicated (bacterial causes) per clinician

symptoms: Rapid heart rate and rapid breathing
Signs of localized infection (e.g., wound redness, cough)
precautions: Prevent infections with hygiene, vaccination, wound care, and safe catheter practices
Timely treatment of infections to reduce progression risk
Recognize early warning signs (fever, confusion, fast breathing) and seek care quickly
actions: Seek emergency medical care immediately—sepsis is life-threatening
Early broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV fluids per hospital protocol
Source control (drain abscesses, remove infected devices) and organ support as needed

symptoms: Characteristic sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure
Pastia's lines (red streaks in skin folds)
Peeling of skin on fingertips and toes during recovery
precautions: Good hand hygiene and avoid close contact with infected individuals
Exclude from school/childcare until 24 hours after starting antibiotics
Cover coughs and practice respiratory etiquette
actions: See clinician for throat testing and antibiotics if indicated (penicillin or amoxicillin)
Supportive care for fever and hydration
Follow-up to ensure resolution and prevent complications

symptoms: Diffuse rash resembling sunburn, often with peeling skin
Multisystem involvement: vomiting, diarrhea, muscle aches, confusion
precautions: Follow product safety guidance for tampons and wound dressings (change frequently)
Seek prompt care for persistent fever and severe symptoms
Maintain wound hygiene and remove foreign materials promptly
actions: Emergency medical care is required—hemodynamic support and antibiotics
Remove any potential source (tampon, packing, infected tissue)
Monitor and support organ systems in hospital setting (ICU if needed)

symptoms: Vesicular rash on palms, soles, and sometimes buttocks
Irritability and poor feeding in young children
Mild respiratory symptoms in some cases
precautions: Handwashing, especially after diaper changes and contact with children
Exclude symptomatic children from group settings per local guidance
Disinfect toys and surfaces in childcare settings
actions: Supportive care: fluids, pain relief, topical mouth rinses for ulcers
Seek care for signs of dehydration or severe illness
Follow public-health advice during outbreaks

symptoms: Neck stiffness and altered mental status in encephalitic cases
Neurologic deficits and movement disorders in survivors
Often asymptomatic or mild febrile illness in most infected individuals
precautions: Vaccination for travelers and residents in endemic areas as recommended
Use mosquito repellents and bed nets; avoid outdoor exposure at peak mosquito times
Eliminate stagnant water and reduce mosquito breeding sites
actions: Seek urgent medical care for neurologic symptoms
Supportive care in hospital (management of raised intracranial pressure, seizures)
Report cases and follow public-health/ vaccination guidance

symptoms: West Nile fever: fever, headache, body aches, nausea, fatigue
Rash on trunk in some cases
Neuroinvasive disease: meningitis or encephalitis with altered mental status, weakness, seizures
Movement disorders or paralysis in severe cases
precautions: Use mosquito repellent and protective clothing; eliminate standing water
Screen blood supply per local regulations
Follow public-health mosquito control measures
actions: Seek medical evaluation for severe neurologic symptoms
Supportive care; hospitalize for neuroinvasive disease
Report cases to public-health authorities

symptoms: Fatigue and joint swelling that may persist for months
precautions: Avoid mosquito bites (repellents, nets, protective clothing)
Eliminate mosquito breeding sites around living areas
Travelers to endemic areas should take mosquito precautions
actions: Supportive care: fluids, analgesics (acetaminophen) and rest
Seek medical attention for severe symptoms or prolonged arthritis
Public-health vector control during outbreaks

symptoms: Most have mild febrile illness with fever and malaise
Severe disease: hemorrhagic fever, encephalitis, or ocular disease
Muscle pain and headache in many cases
Photophobia or vision changes with ocular involvement
precautions: Avoid contact with infected animals or animal tissues
Use personal protective equipment when handling livestock
Control mosquitoes and animal-vector exposure in endemic settings
actions: Seek medical care for severe illness or hemorrhagic symptoms
Supportive hospital care for severe complications
Notify public-health and veterinary authorities for outbreak control

symptoms: Sudden high fever and severe headache
Muscle aches, dizziness, and neck/back pain
Severe bruising, bleeding from gums or nose, and widespread hemorrhagic signs in advanced disease
precautions: Avoid tick bites with repellents and protective clothing in endemic areas
Use PPE when caring for suspected patients or handling animal tissues
Implement infection control precautions in healthcare settings
actions: Seek urgent medical care—supportive hospital care and strict infection control
Ribavirin may be considered in some settings; follow local guidance
Report cases to public-health authorities and implement outbreak control measures

symptoms: Sudden onset fever and severe headache
Hemorrhagic manifestations (bleeding from gums, GI tract, or skin)
Shock and multi-organ failure in severe disease
precautions: Avoid contact with fruit bats and infected animals in endemic regions
Use strict isolation and PPE for suspected cases
Follow international and local public-health guidance for containment
actions: Immediate isolation and supportive care in specialized facilities
Implement strict infection control and contact tracing
Report to public-health authorities and follow outbreak response protocols

symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle aches, and fatigue
Rash progressing from macules to papules to vesicles and pustules
Lesions may be painful or itchy and involve face, palms, soles, and genital area
Sore throat and cough in some cases
precautions: Avoid close contact with infected persons and contaminated materials
Practice good hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette
Vaccination for high-risk contacts where recommended
actions: Isolation of suspected/confirmed cases until lesions crust and scabs fall off
Supportive care; antivirals (tecovirimat) in severe or high-risk cases per guidance
Contact tracing and public-health notification

symptoms: Shortness of breath and severe respiratory distress in severe cases
Conjunctivitis in some avian influenza strains
precautions: Avoid contact with infected poultry and follow safe handling/slaughter practices
Use PPE when working with birds; control outbreaks in poultry populations
Vaccinate poultry where indicated and follow public-health guidance
actions: Seek immediate medical care for suspected human avian influenza infection
Antiviral therapy (oseltamivir or per guidelines) may be considered
Report to public-health authorities and implement containment measures

symptoms: Vomiting and diarrhea in some cases (more common in children)
precautions: Annual influenza vaccination and good respiratory hygiene
Stay home if ill to avoid spreading infection
Hand hygiene and surface cleaning
actions: Seek medical care if severe symptoms or high-risk conditions are present
Antiviral treatment (e.g., oseltamivir) if indicated and started early
Supportive care: fluids, rest, antipyretics

symptoms: Fatigue and impaired sleep in severe cases
precautions: Avoid known allergens (pollen, dust mites, pet dander) where possible
Use HEPA filters and keep windows closed during high pollen times
Practice nasal saline irrigation and environmental controls
actions: Use antihistamines, nasal corticosteroids, and allergy control measures
See an allergist for testing and immunotherapy if severe or persistent
Monitor and treat associated asthma if present

symptoms: Cough (especially at night or with exercise)
Symptoms triggered by allergens, exercise, cold air, or infections
precautions: Avoid known triggers and maintain an asthma action plan
Use inhaled controller medications as prescribed (e.g., inhaled corticosteroids)
Ensure good indoor air quality and smoking cessation
actions: Follow personalized asthma action plan and use inhalers (bronchodilators for relief)
Seek urgent care for severe exacerbations or if rescue inhaler is ineffective
Regular follow-up with healthcare provider to optimize control
